head.title: POSTINGS: 140,000-Square-Foot Building for Solomon Schechter School Rising in Hartsdale; Evoking the Look of a Jerusalem Street

hedline.hl1: POSTINGS: 140,000-Square-Foot Building for Solomon Schechter School Rising in Hartsdale; Evoking the Look of a Jerusalem Street

abstract.p: 140,000-square-foot building, now rising on West Hartsdale Avenue in Hartsdale, NY, will house Solomon Schechter School of Westchester; designer is Neville Epstein of Perkins Eastman Architects; project is expected to cost about $27 million with first phase completed in August 2001; drawing (M)

block.p: In designing a new building for the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester, Neville Epstein of Perkins Eastman Architects of Manhattan, its architect, wanted to evoke the feeling of a ''sanctuary, combined with a place of learning.''

The 140,000-square-foot building, now rising on West Hartsdale Avenue in Hartsdale, will house the Conservative Jewish day school's middle and high schools. ''It will have the elements of a Jerusalem street, with concrete block towers, an arched entryway and the look of old stone,'' Mr. Epstein said.

In designing a new building for the Solomon Schechter School of Westchester, Neville Epstein of Perkins Eastman Architects of Manhattan, its architect, wanted to evoke the feeling of a ''sanctuary, combined with a place of learning.''

The 140,000-square-foot building, now rising on West Hartsdale Avenue in Hartsdale, will house the Conservative Jewish day school's middle and high schools. ''It will have the elements of a Jerusalem street, with concrete block towers, an arched entryway and the look of old stone,'' Mr. Epstein said.

Now in White Plains, the school provides a comprehensive general and Judaic studies program for kindergarten through eighth grade. ''We've outgrown our present capacity with a student population of 660,'' said Dr. Elliot Spiegel, the headmaster. ''The new building gives us a place to house the middle school, grades 6 through 8, and create a new high school.''

The building's dual religious and academic functions will be evident from the entryway, he said. ''You'll be able to see through to a glass-enclosed two-story library,'' he said. ''And there will be chapels on either side of the entrance, one for the middle school and one for the high school.''

The 24-acre site is zoned for school use and borders Woodlands High School, a public school. Across the street is the Maria Regina High School, a Roman Catholic school. ''We plan to use some facilities at the public school, including the running track,'' Dr. Spiegel said.

Construction will take place in two phases, Dr. Spiegel said. The first, now under way, will include 17 classrooms, four science labs, six seminar rooms, a 25,000-volume library, two chapels, a gymnasium, a cafeteria, a video production lab and offices. It is expected to be completed next August.

The second phase is expected to begin four years after completion of the first. It will add about the same number of classrooms and labs, plus a theater, a pool and a music room, Mr. Epstein said. The entire project is expected to cost about $27 million.
